lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a video and answer comprehension questions about Sam’s interesting job.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Pause the video and ask: “What’s his job?” “What is he doing?” Students choose from SB options or write short answers.
stretchStrategies: Students design a “Volcano Safety Poster” in small groups. They include one fact from the video and one safety idea. Groups present briefly to the class.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can understand and explain what volcanoes are and describe how they affect people and places.
supportStrategies: (Science) Show a volcano photo. Ask: “What is it?” Then ask: “What can it do?” Students list facts from the video.
stretchStrategies: Students design a “Volcano Safety Poster” in small groups. They include one fact from the video and one safety idea. Groups present briefly to the class.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can discuss and think critically about whether volcanoes are helpful or harmful and explain their ideas.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Critical Thinking) Class debate: “Are volcanoes good or bad?” Students write one reason, then vote and explain their answers.
stretchStrategies: Students design a “Volcano Safety Poster” in small groups. They include one fact from the video and one safety idea. Groups present briefly to the class.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
